name: Mukden Incident
short_desc: Japanese forces stage false flag attack on railway to justify Manchuria invasion
label: 01. Mukden Incident (Sep 18 1931)

name: Marco Polo Bridge
short_desc: Full-scale Second Sino-Japanese War begins with skirmish near Beijing
label: 02. Marco Polo Bridge (Jul 7 1937)

name: France Surrenders
short_desc: Fall of France allows Japan to pressure French Indochina and tighten control
label: 03. France Surrenders (Jun 22 1940)

name: Pearl Harbor
short_desc: Surprise attack on US Pacific Fleet kills 2400+ and brings America into WWII
label: 04. Pearl Harbor (Dec 7 1941)

name: Philippines Attack
short_desc: Japanese forces attack US bases in Philippines hours after Pearl Harbor
label: 05. Philippines Attack (Dec 8 1941)

name: Malaya Attack
short_desc: Japanese forces land in British Malaya beginning conquest of Southeast Asia
label: 06. Malaya Attack (Dec 8 1941)

name: Hong Kong Falls
short_desc: British colony surrenders after 18-day siege; 14000 defenders captured
label: 07. Hong Kong Falls (Dec 8-25 1941)

name: Guam Captured
short_desc: US territory falls to Japanese assault after minimal resistance
label: 08. Guam Captured (Dec 8-10 1941)

name: Thailand Attacked
short_desc: Japanese forces invade Thailand as part of Southeast Asian offensive
label: 09. Thailand Attacked (Dec 8 1941)

name: Wake Island
short_desc: Small US garrison holds out for 15 days before overwhelming Japanese assault succeeds
label: 10. Wake Island (Dec 8-23 1941)

name: Singapore Falls
short_desc: Britain's Gibraltar of the East surrenders; 80000 troops become prisoners
label: 11. Singapore Falls (Feb 15 1942)

name: Darwin Bombing
short_desc: First enemy attack on Australian mainland kills 243 and damages port facilities
label: 12. Darwin Bombing (Feb 19 1942)

name: Bataan Death March
short_desc: 75000 Filipino and American prisoners forced on brutal 65-mile march; thousands die
label: 13. Bataan Death March (Apr 9-18 1942)

name: Doolittle Raid
short_desc: First US air attack on Japanese home islands boosts American morale significantly
label: 14. Doolittle Raid (Apr 18 1942)

name: Coral Sea
short_desc: First naval battle fought entirely by aircraft; tactical Japanese victory but strategic US win
label: 15. Coral Sea (May 4-8 1942)

name: Aleutians Seized
short_desc: Japanese occupy Attu and Kiska islands in only invasion of North American soil
label: 16. Aleutians Seized (Jun 6 1942)

name: Midway
short_desc: Decisive US victory sinks four Japanese carriers and turns tide in Pacific
label: 17. Midway (Jun 4-7 1942)

name: Guadalcanal
short_desc: Six-month campaign establishes first major Allied offensive victory in Pacific
label: 18. Guadalcanal (Aug 7 1942 - Feb 9 1943)

name: Gilbert Islands
short_desc: US forces begin Central Pacific drive with assault on Gilbert Islands
label: 19. Gilbert Islands (Aug 1943 - Nov 1943)

name: Aleutians Retaken
short_desc: US forces recapture Attu and Kiska ending Japanese presence in North America
label: 20. Aleutians Retaken (May 11 - Aug 24 1943)

name: Tarawa
short_desc: Bloody assault on fortified atoll costs 3000 US casualties in 76 hours
label: 21. Tarawa (Nov 20-23 1943)

name: Marshall Islands
short_desc: Central Pacific drive continues with capture of Kwajalein and Majuro
label: 22. Marshall Islands (Jan 31 - Feb 23 1944)

name: Saipan
short_desc: Capture of strategic island brings B-29s within range of Japanese home islands
label: 23. Saipan (Jun 15 - Jul 9 1944)

name: Philippine Sea
short_desc: Great Marianas Turkey Shoot destroys remaining Japanese carrier aviation
label: 24. Philippine Sea (Jun 19-20 1944)

name: Guam Liberated
short_desc: US forces retake Guam completing conquest of Mariana Islands
label: 25. Guam Liberated (Jul 21 - Aug 10 1944)

name: MacArthur Returns
short_desc: General fulfills promise as Allied forces land on Leyte to begin liberation
label: 26. MacArthur Returns (Oct 20 1944)

name: Leyte Gulf
short_desc: Largest naval battle in history destroys remaining Japanese fleet as fighting force
label: 27. Leyte Gulf (Oct 23-26 1944)

name: Philippines Liberation
short_desc: Systematic liberation of Philippine islands from Japanese occupation
label: 28. Philippines Liberation (Oct 17 - Dec 26 1944)

name: Iwo Jima
short_desc: Bloodiest Pacific battle costs 36000 US casualties to secure strategic airfield
label: 29. Iwo Jima (Feb 19 - Mar 26 1945)

name: Flag Raising Suribachi
short_desc: Iconic flag raising on Mount Suribachi becomes symbol of American determination
label: 30. Flag Raising Suribachi (Feb 23 1945)

name: Tokyo Firebombing
short_desc: Single deadliest air raid of war kills 100000+ civilians in massive firestorm
label: 31. Tokyo Firebombing (Mar 9-10 1945)

name: Okinawa
short_desc: Final and largest Pacific battle costs 200000+ lives including 12000 Americans
label: 32. Okinawa (Apr 1 - Jun 22 1945)

name: Yamato Sunk
short_desc: World's largest battleship sunk by US aircraft on suicide mission to Okinawa
label: 33. Yamato Sunk (Apr 7 1945)

name: Indianapolis Sunk
short_desc: Heavy cruiser sunk by submarine after delivering atomic bomb components; 879 die
label: 34. Indianapolis Sunk (Jul 30 1945)

name: Hiroshima
short_desc: First atomic weapon used in warfare destroys city and kills 80000+ instantly
label: 35. Hiroshima (Aug 6 1945)

name: Nagasaki
short_desc: Second atomic weapon forces Japan's surrender decision; 70000+ killed immediately
label: 36. Nagasaki (Aug 9 1945)

name: Emperor Announces Defeat
short_desc: Emperor Hirohito announces Japan's surrender in radio broadcast; V-J Day celebrated
label: 37. Emperor Announces Defeat (Aug 15 1945)

name: Surrender Signing
short_desc: Formal Japanese surrender signed aboard USS Missouri in Tokyo Bay ends WWII
label: 38. Surrender Signing (Sep 2 1945)
